0.user_question: The Fibonacci sequence is the sequence 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, $\ldots$ where each term is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 4?

ost_step.1: Notice that every third term in the Fibonacci sequence repeats itself modulo 4 as follows: $F_{n} \equiv r^{k},~r=5,$ because it takes three steps before one of the remainders returns again ($[1]=[1], [2]=[-2],[3]=[-1]$). Thus, looking at triples of consecutive integers starting with 1 shows us cycles beginning like so: $\{1; -2; 3\}$. If you multiply them together or add any combination using powers etc., no matter what operation/combination used...you still end up back at your original result! You get something like {$\dots$,[$a$;-$b$;$c$], ... , {$d$;-$e$;$f$} } where everything but $[f]$, i.e.: our target variable here equals zero since adding another full cycle does nothing except resetting ourselves into exactly same position within said set . 0.user_question: The Fibonacci sequence is the sequence 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, $\ldots$ where each term is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 4?

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. Notice that every third term in the sequence is even, so it leaves no remainder upon division by 4. Also notice that alternately starting with odd remainders modulo four results give you back those same remainders again as follows: $$\begin{array}{|c|ccccc} \hline n&F_{n}\pmod{4}\\ \hline 0 & 1\\ 1 & 1\\ 2 & 2\\ 3 & 3 \\ 4 & 1\\ 5 & 1\\ 6 & 2\\ 7 & 3 \\ \hdashline &\cdots&\cdots&\cdots&\cdots &\cdots\end{array}$$ There were three complete cycles up until now ($\{0,\space 3\}, \{1,\space 4\},\space {2,\space 5\}$; $\{6,\space 7\}\implies...$) After one more cycle ($\left\{8,\space 9\right\}$) yields another set giving us $$\bmod(\text{$100^\text{ th}$})=3.$$ Thus, the desired value here would leave a remainder of $3.$ Hence, my final answer is: 3.

1.subquestion: List the remainders as you compute successive values until observing any repetition or pattern emerge.

subanswer.text: Following the recurrence relation $F_{n+1} = (F_n + F_{n-1})$, the following list contains some initial terms along with their respective modulo 4 results:\begin{align*}&(\text{$F_n$} % 4,\quad n=1),\\(&1\%4=1 \\ (\text{$F_n$} % 4,\quad n=2),\qquad&\quad 1\%4=1 \\\ &(\text{$F_n$} % 4,\quad n=3)\qquad &\quad 2\%4=2 \\\ &(\text{$F_n$} % 4,\quad n=4)\qquad &\quad 3\%4=3 \\\ &(\text{$F_n$} % 4,\quad n=5)\qquad &\quad 5\%4=1 \\\end{align*}\[\text{(Here } 5\text{:)}=(3+2)\%4=\color{#c00}{(3+2)}\%4=\color{#c00}{1}%\.]\ \[\text{(Then }\ 6\text{:)=}(5+3)\%4=\color{#c00}{(5+3)}\%4=\color{#c00}{2}%\]\ \[\cdots\] A repeating cycle starts at index $k=5$: $(\mod 4)_{i}^{j}=((i^{'})_{(i)})^{j-5}+1$; here $\{i^{'}, j\}$ denote indices within the cyclical part; i.e., if \(j-5\) exceeds \(\min\{5\}\), set $j'$ accordingly.<|im_sep|>\[(j'-5)_I^{(J)-5}+1 \pmod 4,(1\le I\le J\le K);\;K:=5\]<|\end|>

direct_answer.text:
We know that every fourth Fibonacci number repeats because it follows a periodicity based on congruence properties due to addition operations. Let’s see what happens up till fifth position since everything beyond would repeat itself according to our rule above.\begin{align*}   
   f_0 &= 0                     &&f_0\%4 = 0              \\
   f_1 &= 1                      &&f_1\%4 = 1               \\
   f_2 &= 1                      &&f_2\%4 = 1               \\
   f_3 &= 2                      &&f_3\%4 = 2               \\
   f_4 &= 3                      &&f_4\%4 = 3               \\
   f_5 &= 5                      &&f_5\%4 = 1               \\
       \vdots                                \\
   f_a &= [remainder]            &&f_a\%4 = [\text {new value}]\end{align*}As soon as we reach five positions ($N$), the next element becomes equal to one again — so now we just need to count multiples of four past such first peak.*Note

subanswer.text: After computing some more terms, we have \(F_0 = 1,\ F_1 = 1,\ F_2 = 2,\ F_3 = 3,\ F_4 = 1,\ F_5 = 0,\ F_6 = 1,\ F_7 = 1,\ F_8 = 2,\ F_{10} = 3,\) which shows the repetition after three steps starting at \(\text{Term }~3\). So only Terms divisible by three repeat under division by 4; specifically those whose indices themselves end in either 0 or 3 (\(\mod 4\)), since their preceding index ends in different digits than them ($\mod 3$). 0.user_question: The Fibonacci sequence is the sequence 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, $\ldots$ where each term is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 4?

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. Notice that every third term in the sequence is even, so it leaves no remainder upon division by 4. Also notice that alternately starting with odd remainders modulo four results give you back those same remainders again as follows: $$\begin{array}{|c|ccccc} \hline n&F_{n}\pmod{4}\\ \hline 0 & 1\\ 1 & 1\\ 2 & 2\\ 3 & 3 \\ 4 & 1\\ 5 & 1\\ 6 & 2\\ 7 & 3 \\ \hdashline &\cdots&\cdots&\cdots&\cdots &\cdots\end{array}$$ There were three complete cycles up until now ($\{0,\space 3\}, \{1,\space 4\},\space {2,\space 5\}$; $\{6,\space 7\}\implies...$) After one more cycle ($\left\{8,\space 9\right\}$) yields another set giving us $$\bmod(\text{$100^\text{ th}$})=3.$$ Thus, the desired value here would leave a remainder of $3.$ Hence, my final answer is: 3.
